When I disable Mylar, this goes away... so I think it's actually a Mylar bug.

Matt, does Open Type work for aspect types?  The problem seems to be that Mylar
is adding those automatically to the type history, but they break a contract
that JDT is realying on by not being possible to create with JavaCore.create(..)
given a resource, hence the following failure:

java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.corext.util.IFileTypeInfo.getContainer
(IFileTypeInfo.java:61)
at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.corext.util.TypeInfo.resolveType(TypeInfo.java:223)

Either way, it looks like Mylar/Java will need to be defensive about the
incopatabilities with aspect IType's (Mylar/AspectJ can do fancier stuff). 
Given an IType or TypeInfo, do you know of a way to check that it *isn't* an
AspectJ type?
Ron: could you tell me whether you see aspects in the open type dialog?

Mylar is now defensively avoids adding aspect types to the type history.  Thanks to Matt
for the convenient way of distinguishing them (by checking for the "}" in the handle identifier).
 It's a bit of a hack but the Mylar tests should pick up any changes to type signatures.
